items.title: Are 'immense' Arsenal most formidable team in Europe?
items.summary: Mikel Arteta says Bayern Munich are the "best team in Europe" but, after comprehensively beating them, was this the night Arsenal became serious contenders?

items.title: Frank can take heart despite Champions League loss to PSG
items.summary: Thomas Frank can take encouragement from some aspects of Spurs' latest display, despite defeat to Paris St-Germain, says chief football writer Phil McNulty.

items.title: Liverpool's 'lack of intensity' exposed by PSV
items.summary: Champions League analyst Stephen Warnock says that a "lack of intensity" from Liverpool is made it easy for PSV to create opportunities and beat the Premier League champions 4-1 at Anfield.

items.title: ULA aimed to launch up to 10 Vulcan rockets this yearâ€”it will fly just once
items.summary: The company is closer to increasing its Vulcan launch cadence, but it won't happen this year.
items.body: Around this time last year, officials at United Launch Alliance projected 2025 would be their busiest year ever. Tory Bruno, ULAâ€™s chief executive, told reporters the company would launch as many as 20 missions this year, with roughly an even split between the legacy Atlas V launcher and its replacement â€” the Vulcan rocket. Now, itâ€™s likely that ULA will close out 2025 with six flights â€”five with the Atlas V and just one with the Vulcan rocket the company is so eager accelerate into service. Six flights would make 2025 the busiest launch year for ULA since 2022, but it falls well short of the companyâ€™s forecast. Last week, ULA announced its next launch is scheduled for December 15. An Atlas V will loft another batch of broadband satellites for the Amazon Leo network, formerly known as Project Kuiper , from Cape Canaveral Space Force Station, Florida. This will be ULAâ€™s last launch of the year. Read full article Comments

items.title: Running Unsupported iOS on Deprecated Devices
items.summary: Comments

items.title: Forest to reject bids for Anderson  - Thursday's gossip
items.summary: Nottingham Forest to turn down any bids for Elliot Anderson in January, Crystal Palace considering move for Newcastle United's Joe Willock, Chelsea reopen contact with AC Milan keeper Mike Maignan's camp, plus more.

items.title: Sony teases the A7 V, its next flagship midrange camera
items.summary: Sony appears to be ready to announce another addition to its Alpha camera lineup. The company shared an image on the Sony Alpha Instagram account with the text "Chase your dream" and the date December 2 at 9AM EST, which could be a teaser for its next mirrorless camera. It's possible the company haâ€¦

items.title: How 'absolutely criminal' defending cost Newcastle against Marseille
items.summary: Match of the Day's Stephen Warnock explains how Marseille were able to come from behind against Newcastle to win 2-1.

items.title: PSG come from behind twice in eight-goal thriller against Tottenham
items.summary: PSG score five, including a Vitinha hat-trick, as they defeat Tottenham Hotspur 5-3 in a thriller at Parc des Princes.

items.title: Basketball player, 20, dies after college game
items.summary: A junior college basketball player dies following a head injury during a game in Texas on Saturday.

items.title: Bring Bathroom Doors Back to Hotels
items.summary: Comments

items.title: Arsenal beat Bayern after dominant second-half display
items.summary: Noni Madueke scores his first goal for Arsenal as the Gunners put three past Bayern Munich to maintain their 100% record in the Champions League.

items.title: The Disney+ Hulu bundle drops to $5 per month for one year for Black Friday
items.summary: Disney fans and binge-watchers, rejoice. The Disney+ and Hulu bundle (with ads) is getting a holiday discount again this year, bringing both platforms together for one low price of $5 per month for one year. The bundle includes the Disney+ basic plan with ads and Huluâ€™s basic plan with ads. If youâ€™â€¦

items.title: Liverpool bad form continues as PSV win at Anfield
items.summary: Liverpool's torrid run continues as they suffer a miserable 4-1 home defeat by PSV in the Champions League.

items.title: 'Nothing has changed' - SRU chief backs Townsend
items.summary: Gregor Townsend retains the full support of Scottish Rugby, according to chief executive Alex Williamson, who expects the national head coach to see out his contract through to the 2027 Rugby World Cup.

items.title: Napoli earn hard-fought win over Qarabag
items.summary: Scott McTominay's header and an own goal from Marko Jankovic give Napoli a crucial home win over Qarabag on 5th anniversary of club legend, Diego Maradona's, death.

items.title: Best Black Friday streaming deals for 2025: One year of the Disney+ Hulu bundle for $60, plus save on Apple TV+, HBO Max and more
items.summary: Youâ€™re not alone if youâ€™re consistently aghast at the rising cost of streaming services. This year in particular has been bleak, with Disney+ and HBO Max being just a couple of the services that have increased prices as of late. If youâ€™re like any of us at Engadget, you probably subscribe to more tâ€¦

items.title: Aubameyang scores rapid double as Marseille beat Newcastle
items.summary: Pierre-Emerick Aubameyang scores twice in five minutes as Marseille beat Newcastle United in the Champions League.

items.title: Disjointed Manchester City lose to Leverkusen
items.summary: Pep Guardiola's 100th Champions League game in charge of Manchester City ended in disappointment after the much-changed hosts were stunned by Bayer Leverkusen.

items.title: Estevao stars as Chelsea beat 10-man Barcelona
items.summary: Estevao Willian scores a stunning goal as Chelsea comfortably beat 10-man Barcelona 3-0 at Stamford Bridge in the Champions League.

items.title: Liverpool 'stunned' as Driouech puts PSV 3-1 ahead
items.summary: Couhaib Driouech puts PSV 3-1 ahead against Liverpool at Anfield in teh Champions League. Liverpool go 3-1 down as PSV substitute Couhaib Driouech scores from off the bench.

items.title: Van Dijk gives away penalty as PSV take early lead at Anfield
items.summary: Liverpool captain Virgil van Dijk concedes a penalty after handling the ball and Ivan Perisic scores the resulting penalty to give PSV the lead at Anfield.

items.title: 'Brilliant' Saka corner headed home by Timber
items.summary: Jurrien Timber gives Arsenal the lead against Bayern Munich at the Emirates Stadium.

items.title: An indie studio says it's at risk of closure after Valve banned its game from Steam
items.summary: Indie studio Santa Ragione said it is at risk of shutting down as its latest project won't be available on Steam, which is by far the biggest storefront for PC games and a key point of sale for many developers. Horses, a first-person horror game that blends gameplay and live-action sequences, is abâ€¦

items.title: Solarâ€™s growth in US almost enough to offset rising energy use
items.summary: Over the course of 2025, electricity demand has gradually declined.
items.body: Worries about the US gridâ€™s ability to handle the surge in demand due to data center growth have made headlines repeatedly over the course of 2025. And, early in the year, demand for electricity had surged by nearly 5 percent compared to the year prior, suggesting the grid might truly be facing a data center apocalypse. And that rise in demand had a very unfortunate effect: Coal use rose for the first time since its recent collapse began. But since the first-quarter data was released, demand has steadily eroded. As of yesterdayâ€™s data release by the Energy Information Administration (EIA), which covers the first nine months of 2025, total electricity demand has risen by 2.3 percent. That slowdown means that most of the increased demand could have been met by the astonishing growth of solar power. Better than feared If you look over data on the first quarter of 2025 , the numbers are pretty grim, with total demand rising by 4.8 percent compared to the same period in the year prior. While solar power continued its remarkable surge, growing by an astonishing 44 percent, it was only able to cover a third of the demand growth. As a result of that and a drop in natural gas usage, coal uâ€¦

items.title: RFK Jr.â€™s new CDC deputy director prefers â€œnatural immunityâ€ over vaccines
items.summary: Ralph Abraham is "dangerous," but somehow not the worst among those considered.
items.body: Under ardent anti-vaccine Health Secretary Robert F. Kennedy Jr., the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention has named Louisiana Surgeon General Ralph Abraham as its new principal deputy directorâ€”a choice that was immediately called â€œdangerousâ€ and â€œirresponsible,â€ yet not as bad as it could have been, by experts. Physician Jeremy Faust revealed the appointment in his newsletter Inside Medicine yesterday, which was subsequently confirmed by journalists. Faust noted that a CDC source told him, â€œI heard way worse names floated,â€ and although Abrahamâ€™s views are â€œprobably pretty terrible,â€ he at least has had relevant experience running a public health system, unlike other current leaders of the agency. But Abraham hasnâ€™t exactly been running a health system the way most public health experts would recommend. Under Abrahamâ€™s leadership, the Louisiana health department waited months to inform residents about a deadly whooping cough (pertussis) outbreak. He also has a clear record of anti-vaccine views. Earlier this year, he told a Louisiana news outlet he doesnâ€™t recommend COVID-19 vaccines because â€œI prefer natural immunity.â€ In February, he ordered the health department to stop â€¦

items.summary: Product development, internal operations among teams expected to be hit hardest.
items.body: HP Inc. said that it will lay off 4,000 to 6,000 employees in favor of AI deployments, claiming it will help save $1 billion in annualized gross run rate by the end of its fiscal 2028. HP expects to complete the layoffs by the end of that fiscal year. The reductions will largely hit product development, internal operations, and customer support, HP CEO Enrique Lores said during an earnings call on Tuesday. Using AI, HP will â€œaccelerate product innovation, improve customer satisfaction, and boost productivity,â€ Lores said. Read full article Comments

items.title: Vision Pro M5 review: Itâ€™s time for Apple to make some tough choices
items.summary: A state of the union from someone who actually sort of uses the thing.
items.body: With the recent releases of visionOS 26 and newly refreshed Vision Pro hardware, itâ€™s an ideal time to check in on Appleâ€™s Vision Pro headsetâ€”a device I was simultaneously amazed and disappointed by when it launched in early 2024. I still like the Vision Pro, but I can tell itâ€™s hanging on by a thread. Content is light, developer support is tepid, and while Apple has taken action to improve both, itâ€™s not enough, and Iâ€™m concerned it might be too late. When I got a Vision Pro, I used it a lot: I watched movies on planes and in hotel rooms, I walked around my house placing application windows and testing out weird new ways of working . I tried all the neat games and educational apps, and I watched all the immersive videos I could get ahold of. I even tried my hand at developing my own applications for it. items.summary: Several companies are selling crypto stockpiles in effort to fund share buybacks, shore up stock prices.
items.body: Crypto-hoarding companies are ditching their holdings in a bid to prop up their sinking share prices, as the craze for â€œdigital asset treasuryâ€ businesses unravels in the face of a $1 trillion cryptocurrency rout. Shares in Michael Saylor-led Strategy, the worldâ€™s biggest corporate bitcoin holder, have tumbled 50 percent over the past three months, dragging down scores of copycat companies. About $77 billion has been wiped from the stock market value of these companies, which raise debt and equity to fund purchases of crypto, since their peak of $176 billion in July, according to industry data publication The Block. items.title: Tech firmâ€™s new CTO gets indicted; company then claims he was never CTO
items.summary: Corvex named Brian Raymond as CTO days before indictment for illegal chip exports.
items.body: When four people were arrested and charged with a conspiracy to illegally export Nvidia chips to China, there was an interesting side note. One of the arrestees, Alabama resident Brian Raymond, was the chief technology officer of an AI company called Corvex. Or was he? Corvex certainly seemed to think that Raymond was its CTO in the days before his indictment. Corvex named Raymond as its CTO in a press release and filings to the Securities and Exchange Commission, which detailed plans for a merger with Movano Health. But once Raymond was arrested, Corvex told media outlets that it had never completed the process of hiring him as an employee. While someone could technically be a CTO as a contractor and not a regular employee, a company spokesperson subsequently claimed to Ars that Raymond had never been the CTO. Read full article Comments

items.title: Many genes associated with dog behavior influence human personalities, too
items.summary: But the specific behaviors linked may be completely unrelated.
items.body: Many dog breeds are noted for their personalities and behavioral traits, from the distinctive vocalizations of huskies to the herding of border collies. People have worked to identify the genes associated with many of these behaviors, taking advantage of the fact that dogs can interbreed. But that creates its own experimental challenges, as it can be difficult to separate some behaviors from physical traits distinctive to the breedâ€”small dog breeds may seem more aggressive simply because they feel threatened more often. To get around that, a team of researchers recently did the largest gene/behavior association study within a single dog breed. Taking advantage of a population of over 1,000 golden retrievers, they found a number of genes associated with behaviors within that breed. A high percentage of these genes turned out to correspond to regions of the human genome that have been associated with behavioral differences as well. But, in many cases, these associations have been with very different behaviors. Gone to the dogs The work, done by a team based largely at Cambridge University, utilized the Golden Retriever Lifetime Study, which involved over 3,000 owners of these dogs fâ€¦

items.title: Plexâ€™s crackdown on free remote streaming access starts this week
items.summary: Roku users will be hit first.
items.body: Plex is starting to enforce its new rules, which prevent users from remotely accessing a personal media server without a subscription fee. Previously, people outside of a server ownerâ€™s network could access the ownerâ€™s media library through Plex for free. Under the new rules announced in March , a server owner needs to have a Plex Pass subscription, which starts at $7 per month, to grant users remote access to their server. Alternatively, someone can remotely access another personâ€™s Plex server by buying their own Plex Pass or a Remote Watch Pass , which is a subscription with fewer features than a Plex Pass and that Plex started selling in April for a $2/month starting price. Plexâ€™s new rules took effect on April 29. According to a recent Plex forums post by a Plex employee that How-To Geek spotted today, the changes are rolling out this week, with a subscription being required for people using Plexâ€™s Roku OS app for remote access. The Plex employee added: Read full article Comments

items.title: GPU prices are coming to earth just as RAM costs shoot into the stratosphere
items.summary: Some RAM kits are over three times as expensive as they were three months ago.
items.body: Itâ€™s not a bad time to upgrade your gaming PC. Graphics card prices in the 2020s have undulated continuously as the industry has dealt with pandemic and AI-related shortages, but itâ€™s actually possible to get respectable mainstream- to high-end GPUs like AMDâ€™s Radeon RX 9060 XT and 9070 series or Nvidiaâ€™s RTX 5060 , 5070 , and 5080 series for at or slightly under their suggested retail prices right now. This was close to impossible through the spring and summer. But itâ€™s not a good time to build a new PC or swap your older motherboard out for a new one that needs DDR5 RAM. And the culprit is a shortage of RAM and flash memory chips that has suddenly sent SSD and (especially) memory prices into the stratosphere, caused primarily by the ongoing AI boom and exacerbated by panic-fueled buying by end users and device manufacturers. To illustrate just how high things have jumped in a short amount of time, letâ€™s compare some of the RAM and storage prices listed in our system guide from three months ago to the pricing for the exact same components today. Note that several of these are based on the last available price and are currently sold out; we also havenâ€™t looked into things like micâ€¦

items.summary: So the First Ashes Test didn't go well - but there are still reasons to be cheerful.

items.title: We may need a fourth law of thermodynamics for living systems
items.summary: The laws of thermodynamics don't accurately account for the complex processes in living cells â€“ do we need a new one to accurately measure the ways living systems are out of equilibrium?

items.title: China launches an emergency lifeboat to bring three astronauts back to Earth
items.summary: This is a "successful example for efficient emergency response in the international space industry."
items.body: An unpiloted Chinese spacecraft launched late Monday and linked up with the countryâ€™s Tiangong space station a few hours later, providing a lifeboat for three astronauts stuck in orbit without a safe ride home. A Long March 2F rocket fired its engines and lifted off with the Shenzhou 22 spacecraft, carrying cargo instead of a crew, at 11:11 pm EST Monday (04:11 UTC Tuesday). The spacecraft docked with the Tiangong station nearly 250 miles (400 kilometers) above the Earth about three-and-a-half hours later. Chinese engineers worked fast to move up the launch of the Shenzhou 22, originally set to fly next year. On November 4 , astronauts discovered one of the two crew ferry ships docked to the Tiangong station had a damaged window, likely from an impact with a small fragment of space junk. The crew members used a microscope to photograph the defect from different angles, confirming a small triangular area with a crack, Zhou Jianping, chief designer of Chinaâ€™s human spaceflight program, told Chinese state media . Read full article Comments

items.title: Landlordsâ€™ go-to tool to set rent prices to be gutted under RealPage settlement
items.summary: RealPage agrees to settle suit over DOJ claims software raised rents across the US.
items.body: RealPage has agreed to settle an antitrust lawsuit raised by the Department of Justice, alleging that landlords used its tools to coordinate efforts to artificially raise rental prices across the US. In a press release , the DOJ promised the proposed settlement â€œwould help restore free market competition in rental markets for millions of American renters.â€ For years since the pandemic started, rental prices outpaced inflation, and the DOJ suspected that RealPage was the dominant force driving a market that never favored renters. Recent Bureau of Labor Statistics data covering a 12-month period ending this September showed rents are still rising by 3.5 percent amid an affordability crisis, leaving some US renters in fear of housing instability. Read full article Comments

items.title: Valveâ€™s Steam Machine looks like a console, but donâ€™t expect it to be priced like one
items.summary: Upcoming gaming box will be priced in line with a similarly specced PC, Valve says.
items.body: After Valve announced its upcoming Steam Machine living room box earlier this month, some analysts suggested to Ars that Valve could and should aggressively subsidize that hardware with â€œloss leaderâ€ pricing that leads to more revenue from improved Steam software sales. In a new interview with YouTube channel Skill Up , though, Valveâ€™s Pierre-Loup Griffais ruled out that kind of console-style pricing model, saying that the Steam Machine will be â€œmore in line with what you might expect from the current PC market.â€ Griffais said the AMD Zen 4 CPU and RDNA3 GPU in the Steam Machine were designed to outperform the bottom 70 percent of machines that opt-in to Valveâ€™s regular hardware survey . And Steam Machine owners should expect to pay roughly what they would for desktop hardware with similar specs, he added. â€œIf you build a PC from parts and get to basically the same level of performance, thatâ€™s the general price window that we aim to be at,â€ Griffais said. Read full article Comments

items.title: Formation of oceans within icy moons could cause the waters to boil
items.summary: A rigid ice shell over a shrinking interior makes for pressures low enough to boil.
items.body: Our exploration of the outer Solar System has revealed a host of icy moons, many with surface features that suggest a complex geology. In some cases, these featuresâ€”most notably the geysers of Enceladusâ€”hint at the presence of oceans beneath the icy surfaces. These oceans have been ascribed to gravitational interactions that cause flexing and friction within the moon, creating enough heat to melt the bodyâ€™s interior. Something that has received a bit less attention is that some of these orbital interactions are temporary or cyclical. The orbits of any body are not always regular and often have long-term cycles. Thatâ€™s also true for the other moons that provide the gravitational stress. As a result, the internal oceans may actually come and go, as the interiors of the moons melt and refreeze. A new study, released today by Nature Astronomy, looks at one of the consequences of the difference in density between liquid water and ice (about 10 percent): the potential for the moonâ€™s interior to shrink as it melts, leaving an area of low pressure immediately below its icy shell. If the moon is small enough, this study suggests, that could cause the surface of the ocean to boil. Read fullâ€¦

items.title: Mushroom foragers collect 160 species for food, medicine, art, andÂ science
items.summary: Researchers seek to understand the various uses of wild mushroom species.
items.body: Like many mushroom harvesters, I got interested in foraging for fungi during the COVID-19 pandemic. I had been preparing for a summer of field work studying foraged desert plants in a remote part of Australia when the pandemic hit, and my travel plans were abruptly frozen. It was March, right before morel mushrooms emerge in central Pennsylvania. I wasnâ€™t doing a lot other than going on long hikes and taking classes remotely at Penn State for my doctoral degree in ecology and anthropology . One of the classes was an agroforestry class with Eric Burkhart . We studied how agriculture and forests benefit people and the environment. Read full article Comments

items.title: Anthropic introduces cheaper, more powerful, more efficient Opus 4.5 model
items.summary: Longer chats address a long-standing criticism of Claude.
items.body: Anthropic today released Opus 4.5 , its flagship frontier model, and it brings improvements in coding performance, as well as some user experience improvements that make it more generally competitive with OpenAIâ€™s latest frontier models. Perhaps the most prominent change for most users is that in the consumer app experiences (web, mobile, and desktop), Claude will be less prone to abruptly hard-stopping conversations because they have run too long. The improvement to memory within a single conversation applies not just to Opus 4.5, but to any current Claude models in the apps. Users who experienced abrupt endings (despite having room left in their session and weekly usage budgets) were hitting a hard context window (200,000 tokens). Whereas some large language model implementations simply start trimming earlier messages from the context when a conversation runs past the maximum in the window, Claude simply ended the conversation rather than allow the user to experience an increasingly incoherent conversation where the model would start forgetting things based on how old they are. Read full article Comments

items.title: Rivals object to SpaceXâ€™s Starship plans in Floridaâ€”whoâ€™s interfering with whom?
items.summary: "We're going to continue to treat any LOX-methane vehicle with 100 percent TNT blast equivalency."
items.body: The commander of the military unit responsible for running the Cape Canaveral spaceport in Florida expects SpaceX to begin launching Starship rockets there next year. Launch companies with facilities near SpaceXâ€™s Starship pads are not pleased. SpaceXâ€™s two chief rivals, Blue Origin and United Launch Alliance, complained last year that SpaceXâ€™s proposal of launching as many as 120 Starships per year from Floridaâ€™s Space Coast could force them to routinely clear personnel from their launch pads for safety reasons. This isnâ€™t the first time Blue Origin and ULA have tried to throw up roadblocks in front of SpaceX. The companies sought to prevent NASA from leasing a disused launch pad to SpaceX in 2013, but they lost the fight. Read full article Comments

items.title: Mosquito proboscis repurposed as a fine nozzle for 3D printing
items.summary: When engineers struggled to make 3D printer nozzles narrow enough for their needs, they turned to nature and found the proboscis of a female mosquito had exactly the properties they needed

items.title: Climate heating has reached even deepest parts of the Arctic Ocean
items.summary: The depths of the Arctic Ocean have warmed more than scientists expected. New research has placed the blame on warmer water from Greenland

items.title: How a new way of thinking about fat could transform your health
items.summary: Body fat, often reviled, is actually a vital organ that contributes to your health and well-being. It is time for us to stop vilifying fat and to start exploring how we can harness its power

items.title: Is there any evidence that playing music to plants is beneficial?

items.title: Brian Eno and Beatie Wolfe discuss their new spacebound album, Liminal
items.summary: Brian Eno and Beatie Wolfe's album Liminal is being transmitted into space by Nobel laureate Robert Wilson. They give Chelsea Whyte the lowdown

items.title: New Scientist recommends the Society of Wildlife Artists' annual expo

items.title: A fascinatingly grisly guide to replacing and repairing body parts

items.title: Imagining a future where smart glasses allow 'AI slop' to be avoided
items.summary: In the latest in our imagined history of inventions yet to come, Future Chronicles columnist Rowan Hooper reveals how an ingenious way to avoid being swamped by AI content was invented in the late 2020s

items.title: Cars are getting bigger. This is a problem for us and for the planet

items.title: Who finds dad jokes funniest? The answer might not astonish you

items.title: An ambitious look at quantum physics is fun â€“ but overdoes it a little
items.summary: Attempts to describe quantum physics are rarely enjoyable, but Paul Davies' zeal in Quantum 2.0 sometimes steers too close to hype, finds Karmela Padavic-Callaghan

items.title: Why quasicrystals shouldnâ€™t exist but are turning up in strange places

items.title: Quantum computers that recycle their qubits can limit errors
items.summary: To make quantum computers more efficient and reliable, some of their basic components must be constantly reused â€“ several quantum computer designs can now do just that

items.title: Physics of light and magnetism rewritten after almost two centuries

items.title: Kissing may have evolved in an ape ancestor 21 million years ago
items.summary: Rather than being a recent cultural development, kissing may have been practised by other early humans like Neanderthals and our ape ancestors

items.summary: AlphaEvolve, an AI system created by Google DeepMind, is helping mathematicians do research at a scale that was previously impossible - even if it does occasionally "cheat" to find a solution

items.title: 'It felt like God's hand on my brain' - the day England were humbled by teenager

items.summary: The discovery that fat is a communicative organ with a role in everything from bone health to mood is forcing a rethink of how we view our bodies

items.title: Cuts and scrapes may be slower to heal in redheads

items.summary: Physics has a reputation for being dominated by men, especially a century ago, as quantum physics was just being invented â€“ but there have been so many women who helped shaped the field since its inception

items.title: Analysing Hitler's DNA for a TV gimmick tells us nothing useful
items.summary: To understand Adolf Hitler, we need to look at his personal life and the wider societal and historical context - analysing his DNA for a TV gimmick tells us nothing, says Michael Le Page

items.title: Why aren't young people having sex any more?
items.summary: Sexual activity in young people is on the decline, but why? And what's more, should we be worried about what this means for society and the future of the human race?

items.title: The great number nine decline - where have England's strikers gone?
items.summary: BBC Sport takes an in-depth look at why England lack centre-forward options behind Harry Kane - a far cry from when the likes of Les Ferdinand only won 17 caps.

items.title: Fossil fuel emissions rise again â€“ but China's are levelling off
items.summary: Global emissions from fossil fuels are expected to hit another record high in 2025, but Chinaâ€™s carbon emissions appear to be reaching a peak

items.title: Strongest evidence yet that the Epstein-Barr virus causes lupus
items.summary: Lupus has been linked to the Epstein-Barr virus â€“ which causes glandular fever, or mono â€“ before, but we now have evidence of how it can bring about the autoimmune condition

items.title: Finally wrangling with the complexity of female bodies benefits us all
items.summary: Medical research has long sought to gloss over the hormonal and chromosomal complications typical of female biology. But embracing this complexity could benefit everyone

items.title: The 19th-century maths that can help you deal with horrible coffee
items.summary: Do you need to fairly allocate players to teams, or sort out a pot of badly brewed coffee? Katie Steckles has a mathematical solution

items.title: Breaking Bad showrunner uses sci-fi for smart dive into happiness
items.summary: Vince Gilligan, the showrunner behind Breaking Bad and Better Call Saul, is back, this time using sci-fi to explore a deceptively rich premise about the pursuit of happiness and the notion of utopia, finds Bethan Ackerley

items.title: New Scientist recommends this extreme birdwatching documentary
items.summary: The books, TV, games and more that New Scientist staff have enjoyed this week

items.title: Smart new book takes an axe to the myth of human exceptionalism
items.summary: Christine Webb's provocative and moving book The Arrogant Ape explores our unjustifiable sense of superiority in the living world, laying out the evidence against it, says Elle Hunt

items.title: Is the future of education outside universities?
items.summary: New technologies and academic funding cuts are upending the ways we learn today. Newly enrolled student Annalee Newitz finds some silver linings

items.title: Sperm are selfish â€“ and so are we
items.summary: A new study hammers home how the "survival of the nicest" view makes no sense when it comes to evolution, says Jonathan R. Goodman

items.title: Surprising new biography of Francis Crick unravels the story of DNA
items.summary: Francis Crick's biography is full of surprises as author Matthew Cobb reveals the life and work of the co-discoverer of DNA's structure, finds Michael Le Page

items.title: Kim Kardashian has wrangled an invite to NASA HQ. Can we get one too?
items.summary: Reality TV star Kim Kardashian apparently thinks the 1969 moon landing was fake. If Feedback comes up with an equally outlandish conspiracy theory, maybe we can also get a guided tour of NASA

items.title: Remarkable robot images provide a vision of the future
items.summary: These photographs of humanoid robots by Henrik Spohler are part of his project Tomorrow Is the Question

items.title: Sex could help wounds heal faster by reducing stress
items.summary: Mild wounds healed faster if people took a spray containing the "love hormone" oxytocin and set aside time to praise their partner â€“ but they cleared up even quicker if these individuals were also intimate with their other half

items.title: Huge cloud of plasma belched out by star 130 light years away
items.summary: A coronal mass ejection from a distant star has been confirmed for the first time, raising questions about how such events could impact exoplanet habitability

items.title: Is a deadly asteroid about to hit Earth? Meet the man who can tell you
items.summary: When an asteroid threatens Earth, astronomers use a rating called the Torino scale to communicate the risk. Richard Binzel, who invented the scale, tells New Scientist about his 50-year career in planetary defence

items.title: Chemical computer can recognise patterns and perform multiple tasks
items.summary: Previous attempts at building a chemical computer have been too simple, too rigid or too hard to scale, but an approach based on a network of reactions can perform multiple tasks without having to be reconfigured

items.title: Women prefer to be prettier than a partner, but men want to be funnier
items.summary: When measuring yourself against your partner, which traits do you prefer to have compared with your significant other? A survey that forced people to choose has found that men and women have different preferences when it comes to being smarter, funnier or more attractive

items.title: IBM has unveiled two unprecedentedly complex quantum computers
items.summary: IBM revealed two new quantum computers, called Loon and Nighthawk â€“ the qubits they use are connected in newly intricate ways and may enable a way to run error-free computations

items.title: Cradle of humanity is still revealing new insights about our origins
items.summary: The Omo-Turkana basin in Africa is home to a treasure trove of ancient human fossils and tools that span 300,000 years â€“ today it is still yielding new discoveries about our species

items.title: At-home hypnosis relieves menopausal hot flushes
items.summary: Hot flushes could be relieved by listening to recordings that induce hypnosis from home, rather than having to venture to a clinic

items.title: Women have supercharged immune systems and we now know why
items.summary: Being born with two X chromosomes brings a host of health benefits, and recognising this could lead to personalised medical treatments for men and women

items.title: Static electricity can remove frost from windows using little energy
items.summary: High-voltage copper plates can remove up to three-quarters of frost from a surface, while using much less energy than conventional heating

items.title: Odds of asteroid 2024 YR4 hitting the moon may rise to 30 per cent
items.summary: In February, the James Webb Space Telescope will briefly be able to observe asteroid 2024 YR4, which currently has a 4 per cent chance of hitting the moon in 2032. Depending on what it sees, the odds of collision could drastically increase

items.title: The biggest controversy in maths could be settled by a computer
items.summary: For over a decade, mathematicians have failed to agree whether a 500-page proof is actually correct. Now, translating the proof into a computer-readable form may finally settle the matter

items.title: Caves carved by water on Mars may hold signs of past life
items.summary: Eight possible cave openings found on the Martian surface look to have once had ancient streams flowing into them, suggesting they are promising places to look for evidence of life

items.title: Why giving up on goals is good for you, and how to know which to ditch
items.summary: We admire grit and perseverance, but surprising research suggests that giving up on ambitions in the right way can actually improve our physical and mental health

items.title: Falling asleep isnâ€™t a gradual process â€“ it happens all of a sudden
items.summary: Brain activity from more than 1000 people shows a rapid transition from being awake to being asleep, rather than a slow transition between the two states

items.title: AI may blunt our thinking skills â€“ hereâ€™s what you can do about it
items.summary: There is growing evidence that our reliance on generative AI tools is reducing our ability to think clearly and critically, but it doesnâ€™t have to be that way

items.title: Could electric race cars soon be faster than Formula 1?
items.summary: The electric cars of the Formula E racing championship can accelerate faster than Formula 1 cars and their top speeds are catching up â€“ but battery capacity would let them down in a head-to-head

items.title: When rift lakes dry up it can cause earthquakes and eruptions
items.summary: Lake Turkana in Kenya, known as the cradle of humanity, has shrunk in recent millennia â€“ and the loss of water has led to increased seismic activity, which could have impacted our ancient ancestors

items.title: AI power use forecast finds the industry far off track to net zero
items.summary: Several large tech firms that are active in AI have set goals to hit net zero by 2030, but a new forecast of the energy and water required to run large data centres shows theyâ€™re unlikely to meet those targets

items.title: Mysterious holes in Andean mountain may be an Inca spreadsheet
items.summary: Thousands of holes arranged in a snake-like pattern on Monte Sierpe in Peru could have been a monumental accounting device for trade and tax

items.title: James Watson, co-discoverer of DNAâ€™s double helix, has died aged 97
items.summary: As one of the most influential scientists of the 20th century, James Watson pioneered the field of genetics and left behind a complicated legacy

items.title: Enceladusâ€™s ocean may be even better for life than we realised
items.summary: The buried ocean on Saturnâ€™s moon Enceladus seems to be stable across extremely long periods of time, making it an even more promising place to hunt for life

items.title: Here's how to spot the Leonid meteor shower this month
items.summary: A new moon on 20 November means there is a great opportunity to enjoy the Leonid meteor shower this year, says Abigail Beall. Just make sure to get warm and comfy first

items.title: What weâ€™re learning about consciousness from master meditatorsâ€™ brains
items.summary: Neuroscientist Matthew Sacchet is revealing how mastering meditation can not only enable transcendental states of bliss, but also reshape how we experience pain and emotion

items.title: How preppers plan to save us if the whole internet collapses
items.summary: Recent outages have revealed how vulnerable the internet is, but there seems to be no official plan in the event of a catastrophic failure. Meet the team of hackers who are ready to jump into action

items.title: Our bodies are ageing faster than ever. Can we hit the brakes?
items.summary: All over the world people are ageing more rapidly and succumbing to diseases that typically affected the elderly. But there are ways to turn back the clock on your biological age
